seg.seg: The fourth is the thirst for the Saṃsāra ... [85c] ... [85d] ...
in the five forms of existence. (The thirst for Saṃsāra?), just as if having become a creeper ... [86b] Thereby the beings ...

renounce (the thirst?)! [86d] Then he spoke (in the assembly two verses), to evoke the world weariness of the monks. “(By whichever [thirst] bound gods and men) are standing here desiring ... [87b] ...
... von dem (Durst?) macht Abkehr!
... from the (thirst?) turn away!

(Überwindet dieses Verlangen, durch welches gebunden, Götter [und] Menschen) hier verlangend (stehen); der [rechte] Augenblick darf von euch nicht übergangen werden [oder: darf an euch nicht vorübergehen]. Die den [rechten] Augenblick übergangen haben, sind betrübt; in die Höllen [sind] sie (von) [ihren] Taten geführt.

(Overcome this desire, bound by which gods [and] humans stand) here, longing; the [right] moment must not be passed over by you [or: must not pass you]. Those [who] have passed over the [right] moment are deject; into the hells they [have been] led (by) [their] deeds.

the [right] moment must not be passed by you. Those that have passed the [right] moment are sorrowful, they have been led into hell by [their] deeds. [87d] (The thirst) [is] the cause, the running one, the one (clinging to) everything ...
Der [rechte] Augenblick darf von euch nicht übergangen werden. Die den [rechten] Augenblick übergangen haben, sind betrübt, in die Höllen [sind] sie (von) ]ihren] Taten geführt.
The [right] moment must not be missed by you. Those who have missed the [right] moment are sad, into hell they [are] brought (by) [their] deeds.
the one having gone astray, the one having a net. If the liana, the one longing to drink, one has removed in every way, the suffering will turn away again and again. This strophe ...
Wenn man die Liane, die nach Trinken Verlangen habende, in jeder Beziehung beseitigt hat, wendet sich dieses Leiden wieder [und] wieder ab.
If the liana, desiring to drink, has been removed in every respect, this suffering will turn away again [and] again.

recognize as a fault (of the thirst)! [88d] Again he spoke another strophe: “Just as, if the roots have not obtained damage, a tree, even if it has been cut down, will be born again, (so [will] the thirst)

Again he spoke another strophe: «[Just] as when the roots have not got damage a tree rises a second time if it is cut off … (so, if the roots of thirst) are not torn out with the consequences, the great wheel of sorrow of the beings turns again and again.» (cf : ii, 18)

[89b] (If the roots of the thirst) have not been pulled out with its remains, the beings’ big wheel of suffering will turn on and on. [98d] (Just like) the arrow, too, the one (made) firm by [him]self, (should kill even himself) ...
(Wenn die Wurzeln des Durstes) mit den Konsequenzen nicht herausgerissen wurden, dreht sich das große Leidensrad der Wesen wieder [und] wieder.
(If the roots of thirst) were not torn out with the consequences, the big wheel of suffering of the beings turns again [and] again.

if he, having arisen with power, entered even into him, in this way here also (the thirst) will lead, if it has arisen like liana from within, the beings towards (death). This (third strophe he proclaimed to them. [90d] In this way)

many faults arise in the beings from the affliction of thirst. Only to [their] disappearance the teachers have gathered such strophes in (this Udā)na. [91b] Four-legged are (thoughts) of saturation ...
(Derartig) entstehen [wtl. erheben sich] viele Fehler der Wesen aus der Trübung Durst.
(In this way) many errors of the beings arise from the affliction [that is] thirst.
The all-killing affliction of thirst here generates the insatiability of the good beings. [91d] In cause and effect it deceives (here) the beings, excites them and gladdens them. (Insatiability) ...
In Ursache [und] Wirkung täuscht (sie [scil. die Trübung Durst] hier) die Wesen, regt [sie] auf [und] macht ihnen Freude.
In cause [and] effect (here it [i.e. the defilement thirst]) deceives the beings, excites [them] [and] gladdens them.
Die alles tötende Trübung Durst erzeugt hier die Unersättlichkeit der Wesen.
The defilement of thirst, killing all, here creates the insatiability of the good beings.
the Saṃsāra-tree (burns?) long in the fires. The affliction that is thirst does not let it wither. The water of thirst moistens (its) roots, makes him new again [92d] ...
the teachers, the ones knowing the śāstra: “If there is water in the pond, it will please the animals there, the fish, etc. [93b] Just like this one, (in) whose (mind) is the water of thirst ...

If there is water in a pond, the animals there, the fishes, and so on, rejoice themselves. Likewise, in whose mind is the water of thirst … the kleśa animals feel happy in his thought and mind and do not leave him alone. (cf : ii, 19)

Wenn Wasser im Teich ist, finden dort Gefallen die Tiere, Fische, usw. So [auch] (in) wessen (Geist) das Wasser des Durstes ist ..., die (Trübungs)tiere fühlen sich in dessen Denken [und] Fühlen wohl, sie verlassen ihn nicht.

If there is water in the pond, the animals, fish, etc. enjoy it there. Thus [also] (in) whose (mind) there is the water of thirst ... , the animals (of defilement) feel good in his thought [and] feeling, they do not leave him.
the animals (of affliction) are happy in his mind and thinking, they do not abandon him. [93d] The affliction that is thirst harms the beings in the Saṃsāra and depresses them ...
having given [up] the life everywhere. However many (animals) [there are] in the ocean, ... because of thirst (they are) like blinded. [94c] Whose ... able (to protect them)? [94d] ...
deception he makes in fivefold ways ... he does (for) the gain ...
... macht er des Gewinnes (wegen) ...
... he does (for the sake) of profit ...
if he obtains this in spirit ...

p.note: Contains strophes 85c-95 of the Tṛṣṇāvarga (III). The metre is 4x18 syllables in a 7/7/4 rhythm.

The original manuscript is missing, but was a larger fragment of leaf 49, pieced together from various smaller fragments and containing about 3/4 of the complete length of the leaf, with large gaps partly caused by fire.
Additions according to II, 17 fn. 8 and 11.
Addition at the end of the line according to 158.
Additions according to II, 18 fn. 10 and 14.
According to 159 the reading tetkorsa should be corrected to nenkorsa in the transcription.
In the current reading the first colon of pāda 92d lacks one syllable.

div.head: Sanskrit parallel
div.p: corresponds to Uv. III, 14: yayā devā manuṣyāś ca sitās tiṣṭhanti hārthikāḥ tarataitāṃ viṣaktikāṃ kṣaṇo vo mā hy upatyagāt kṣaṇātītā hi śocante narakeṣu samarpitāḥ
Attachment, on which gods and men depend and which they seek, reject it; do not let the moment pass; those who let the moment pass suffer in the hells where they are cast.
corresponds to Uv. III, 15: tṛṣṇā hi hetuḥ saritā viṣaktikā gaṇḍasya nityaṃ visṛteha jālinī latāṃ pipāsām apanīya sarvaśo nivartate duhkham idaṃ punaḥ punaḥ

In truth craving is the source of the river, attachment is the root of the trunk and spreads like a net here; if one wholly avoids that creeper which is craving (of desires), suffering moves away forever.
corresponds to Uv. III, 16: yathāpi mūlair anupadrutaiḥ sadā chinno ’pi vṛkṣaḥ punar eva jāyate evaṃ hi tṛṣṇānuśayair anuddhṛtair nirvartate duhkham idaṃ punaḥ punaḥ
Just as, so long as its root is intact, a tree, even though cut down, grows ever again, so, as long as the attachments of craving are not eradicated, suffering returns ever and again.
corresponds to Uv. III, 17: yathāpi śalyo dṛḍhaṃ ātmanā kṛtas tam eva hanyād balasā tv adhiṣṭhitaḥ tathā tv ihādhyātma samutthitā latās tṛṣṇā vadhāyopanayanti prāṇinām
Like a home-made arrow which hits you when it has been badly positioned, so craving leads the creepers which grow on the terrain on the personality to strike living beings.
